body.p:
Louisville January 18. 1861
To His Excellency
Govr. Magoffin
My Dear Sir.

Enclosed herewith I send you a petition in the case of the Commonwealth vs Christian Shroeder signed by all the petit jury. The Judge Comths atto, Sheriff and Clerk. All of the bystanders would have cheerfully signed the petition if it had been deemed necessary. I am also authorized to say that Messrs Bills & Co and Messrs Quigley Lyons & Co, the parties whose interests were involved in the transaction, were not at all disposed to prosecute the defendant under the full beleif that Hudson in fact forged the check and victamised the defendant for his base purpose, and then absconded with all the money. Shroeder is quite young, a stranger in the city, of very prepossessing manners, and
of industrious habits. His family reside in Indinapolis Inda and ^are^, as I am informed highly respectable. I was employed by them to attend to his case. In my interacions with the accused he has impressed me with the belief that he is conscentious, and in this instance was imposed upon by an artful and designing vilain. He is apparently greatly subdued by the imputation to which he has been subjected, and seems to feel most sensibly its crushing effects upon his aged parents.
I trust you will find it consistent with your sense of duty to save him from the consequences of a sentence to the Penitentiary.

P. S. The officers of the Jail, where this youth has been confined for several months, seem to be deeply impressed with the idea that he is not a fit subject for the Penitentiary and that no moral guilty attaches to him
in this transaction. They would be glad to see him pardoned. I have not procured their signatures to the petition because I did not deem it necessary.

To His Excellency
Govr of Kentucky
Frankfort
Ky
Issue pardon & enclose to Judge W. F. Bullock
